articles.headline: London Ponders Its Future as Financial Powerhouse
articles.snippet: An economist predicts that Britain will soon have the highest budget deficit in the developed world, as the financial services industry wanes.
articles.abstract: An economist predicts that Britain will soon have the highest budget deficit in the developed world, as the financial services industry wanes.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Tetsuya Ishikawa reaped the fruits of London’s financial boom, structuring and selling his small share of the complex securities that fueled both his professional rise and the uninterrupted economic growth of Britain. When the boom went bust last year, he lost his job at Morgan Stanley, along with about 28,000 other Londoners working in finance.

articles.headline: Time for Bank Creditors to Share the Pain?
articles.snippet: If bank balance sheets need bolstering, one remedy is to infuse more taxpayer money, while another is for bank creditors to forgive some loans.
articles.abstract: If bank balance sheets need bolstering, one remedy is to infuse more taxpayer money, while another is for bank creditors to forgive some loans.
articles.lead_paragraph: The big debate about President Obama’s financial rescue plan has centered on whether he’s been right to avoid nationalizing the country’s biggest banks. But there is another, more pressing question about the plan that has received considerably less attention.

articles.headline: Specter Switches Parties; More Heft for Democrats
articles.snippet: The decision by Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania to switch parties potentially presents Democrats with a 60th vote and the power to break Senate filibusters.
articles.abstract: The decision by Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania to switch parties potentially presents Democrats with a 60th vote and the power to break Senate filibusters.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  In an unexpected turnabout in political loyalties, Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania announced on Tuesday that he was leaving the Republican Party to become a Democrat, bolstering President Obama at a pivotal moment for his policy agenda and further marginalizing Republicans on Capitol Hill.
articles.byline: By Carl Hulse and Adam Nagourney

articles.headline: Obama Finds That Saving on Copters Could Be Costly
articles.snippet: More than $3 billion has been spent on a $13 billion presidential helicopter program that the Obama administration considers wasteful and wants to halt.
articles.abstract: More than $3 billion has been spent on a $13 billion presidential helicopter program that the Obama administration considers wasteful and wants to halt.
articles.lead_paragraph: At a Washington conference on fiscal responsibility in February, President Obama tried to set the tone by saying he did not need the new costly presidential helicopters that had been ordered by the Bush administration.

articles.headline: Poppies a Target in Fight Against Taliban
articles.snippet: U.S. commanders hope a troop increase can help cut off the multimillion-dollar opium crop that funds the Taliban.
articles.abstract: U.S. commanders hope a troop increase can help cut off the multimillion-dollar opium crop that funds the Taliban.
articles.lead_paragraph: ZANGABAD, Afghanistan  American commanders are planning to cut off the Taliban’s main source of money, the country’s multimillion-dollar opium crop, by pouring thousands of troops into the three provinces that bankroll much of the group’s operations.

articles.headline: From Édgar, 5, Coughs Heard Round the World
articles.snippet: The Mexican government has identified a young boy as the first person in the country infected with swine flu, but officials have been slow to stem its spread.
articles.abstract: The Mexican government has identified a young boy as the first person in the country infected with swine flu, but officials have been slow to stem its spread.
articles.lead_paragraph: LA GLORIA, Mexico  Édgar Hernández can rattle off the fierce flu symptoms he suffered a few weeks back, like a boy far beyond his five years: His head was hot. He coughed until his belly and his throat were sore. He did not want to eat, which was strange for him, someone who gobbles up everything he can.

articles.headline: Feeling Secure, Some Banks Want to Be Left Alone
articles.snippet: Emboldened by newfound profits and eager to shake off federal control, a growing number of banks are resisting the Obama administration’s proposals for fixing the system.
articles.abstract: Emboldened by newfound profits and eager to shake off federal control, a growing number of banks are resisting the Obama administration’s proposals for fixing the system.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Washington pushes banks to mend their finances, the banks are pushing back.
articles.byline: By Graham Bowley and Eric Dash

articles.headline: Early Resolve: Obama Stand in Auto Crisis
articles.snippet: The automobile industry crisis has tested the new president’s political instincts and activist approach.
articles.abstract: The automobile industry crisis has tested the new president’s political instincts and activist approach.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  By the time he sat down in the Oval Office to brief Michigan’s Congressional delegation, President Obama had made up his mind. Days earlier, he had decided to oust the head of General Motors and give it and Chrysler weeks to fix themselves. If they could not, he was prepared to let them go bankrupt, a prospect fraught with economic and political repercussions.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg, Peter Baker and Bill Vlasic

articles.headline: Economic Decline in Quarter Exceeds Forecast
articles.snippet: The government reported gross domestic product shrank at a 6.1 percent yearly rate, but the numbers suggested that the worst of the recession may be easing.
articles.abstract: The government reported gross domestic product shrank at a 6.1 percent yearly rate, but the numbers suggested that the worst of the recession may be easing.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American economy is contracting at its steepest pace in 50 years, the government reported Wednesday, but an unanticipated rise in consumer spending since January suggested to many economists that the worst of the recession might have passed.
articles.byline: By Louis Uchitelle and Edmund L. Andrews

articles.headline: Bank of America Chief Ousted as Chairman
articles.snippet: Shareholders stripped Kenneth D. Lewis of his chairman title in a vote that may mark the beginning of the end of his leadership at the embattled bank.
articles.abstract: Shareholders stripped Kenneth D. Lewis of his chairman title in a vote that may mark the beginning of the end of his leadership at the embattled bank.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — The applause thundered inside the Belk Theater on Wednesday for a fading star of American finance: Kenneth D. Lewis, the beleaguered head of Bank of America.
